Department of systems, applications and technical support
Department serves as the technological backbone of the Unified Procurement Authority (UPA), enabling efficient procurement operations through custom software development, 24/7 technical support for 50,000+ end-users, secure system integrations with government platforms, and proactive cybersecurity measures compliant with Cybersecurity standards.
Our mission is to empower UPA's procurement ecosystem through reliable, secure, and innovative technology solutions that drive operational excellence. We've achieved significant milestones including reduction in system downtime, enhanced efficiency through modern technologies, complete health asset collection, and 100% compliance in our last security audit.
Used Methodologies
🕒 Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)

📍 Phase 1: Requirement Analysis 🗓️ Start of Project • Engage stakeholders, gather functional and non-functional requirements • Define goals, expectations, scope, constraints • Deliverables: Business Requirements Document (BRD), Software Requirements Specification (SRS)

📍 Phase 2: System Design🗓️ Post-Requirement Approval• Translate requirements into architecture and system structure• Create wireframes, UI/UX flows, database schemas• Deliverables: High-Level Design (HLD), Low-Level Design (LLD), UI mockups 📍 Phase 3: Development🗓️ After Design Approval• Developers begin coding based on agreed technical specifications• Backend, frontend, APIs, integrations, and modules are developed• Deliverables: Source code, dev builds, version-controlled repositories 📍 Phase 4: Testing🗓️ After Code Completion• Quality assurance team performs unit, integration, and system testing• Conduct UAT with stakeholders and verify requirements are met• Deliverables: Test cases, bug reports, verified builds 📍 Phase 5: Deployment🗓️ After Successful Testing• System is deployed to production or live environment• May include staging, pilot rollouts, or full releases• Deliverables: Release documentation, deployment logs 📍 Phase 6: Maintenance🗓️ Post-Deployment / Ongoing• Continuous updates, bug fixes, user support• System monitoring, performance optimization• Deliverables: Maintenance logs, patch notes, user feedback reports

Development technique
Pair Programming
Improved Code Quality
  • With two sets of eyes on the code, errors are caught early. This reduces bugs and improves code structure, logic, and readability.
Faster Problem Solving
  • Collaboration encourages brainstorming and sharing different perspectives. This often leads to faster and more creative solutions.
Knowledge Sharing
  • Pair programming promotes continuous learning. Junior developers can quickly pick up best practices and gain hands-on experience, while seniors can gain new insights or refine their own skills.
Better Team Communication
  • Working closely together fosters open communication and trust, leading to stronger team dynamics and easier collaboration on future projects.
Increased Focus and Discipline
  • Having a partner can reduce distractions and encourage developers to stay focused. It also enforces writing cleaner code since both contributors must understand and agree on the approach.
Onboarding and Mentorship
  • New team members integrate faster by pairing with experienced developers, learning the codebase, tools, and processes through guided participation.
Reduced Knowledge Silos
  • When multiple developers understand the same parts of the codebase, the project becomes more resilient to changes in staffing or responsibility.
Higher Job Satisfaction
  • Many developers find pair programming intellectually stimulating and socially engaging, which can boost morale and job satisfaction.
Tackling complex features or problems
Conducting code reviews in real-time
Onboarding new developers
Working in high-risk or high-stakes areas of code
Deployment Technique
🔁 CI/CD: Continuous Integration & Continuous Deployment
CI/CD is a modern DevOps practice that automates the software development lifecycle, ensuring faster, safer, and more reliable application delivery.
✅ Continuous Integration (CI):
  • Developers frequently push code to a shared repository.
  • Automated tools build, test, and validate code changes.
  • Detects issues early, reduces integration conflicts, and ensures code quality.
🚀 Continuous Deployment/Delivery (CD):
  • Once tested, code is deployed to staging or production environments.
  • Ensures quick, consistent releases with minimal manual intervention.
  • Improves agility, reduces downtime, and supports rolling updates or hotfixes.
🛠️ Used Tools :
  • CI: Jenkins
  • CD: Docker, Bonobo Git, IIS
🎯 Benefits:
  • Faster release cycles
  • Early bug detection
  • Improved collaboration
  • Reduced risk in production
Impact on Organizational Goals
The Department of Systems, Applications, and Technical Support acts as a critical enabler of the Unified Procurement Authority’s (UPA) vision by embedding digital intelligence, operational agility, and technical excellence across all functions. Our initiatives directly accelerate UPA’s ability to meet national objectives and deliver public value.
🌐 1. Driving Government Digitization at Scale
By consolidating fragmented legacy systems into unified, interoperable platforms (e.g., HMIS, UPA Logistics, Pharmacy), we empower the shift from paper-based bureaucracy to data-driven governance. This supports national strategies around smart government, e-health, and digital economy pillars.
🧠 2. Enabling Strategic Decision-Making
We equip leadership with powerful dashboards, custom reporting engines, and real-time analytics that offer clear visibility into operations. These tools translate complex data into actionable intelligence, helping the UPA manage resources more wisely and plan proactively for emergencies.
🤝 3. Building Institutional Resilience and Continuity
Through robust cybersecurity, disaster recovery planning, and maintenance of high-availability systems, we protect UPA’s digital infrastructure. Our efforts ensure that procurement and supply chain functions remain operational during national crises or disruptive events.
🧑‍🏫 4. Strengthening Human Capital through Technology
We invest in capacity building—providing technical workshops, digital literacy initiatives, and user-centered systems to empower staff. By increasing tech adoption across UPA, we reduce dependency on manual processes and foster a culture of innovation and ownership.
🛡️ 5. Ensuring Regulatory Compliance and Public Trust
Our systems are designed with full adherence to regulatory frameworks (e.g., cybersecurity, health IT standards, data privacy laws). We play a vital role in ensuring that UPA’s digital initiatives uphold transparency, accountability, and public trust.
🚀 6. Fostering Innovation and Future-Readiness
We explore and deploy emerging technologies like AI co-pilots, predictive analytics, and event-driven systems to address complex public sector challenges. Our department serves as an internal innovation lab, piloting future-ready solutions that can be scaled across government.
🌍 7. Enabling Strategic Partnerships
Through integrations with entities like the Ministry of Health, ECIC, GAHAC, and the Public Prosecution, we create a unified digital ecosystem that facilitates inter-agency collaboration and information flow—essential for nationwide digital health and procurement initiatives.

Pillars of High-Quality Software: Building Code That Stands the Test of Time
In a world where technology evolves at lightning speed, only software built on solid foundations can keep up. High-quality software isn't just about writing code—it’s about crafting reliable, secure, and scalable systems that deliver seamless performance and stand strong under pressure. It’s code that's easy to maintain, simple to extend, and a joy to use. These pillars—reliability, maintainability, performance, usability, and beyond—are not just best practices; they’re the blueprint for digital excellence. Let’s explore what turns good software into great software.

Latest Projects
Pharmacy
The Central Pharmacy, developed within the Unified Procurement Authority (UPA) system, is a pivotal initiative designed to revolutionize medication dispensing across Egyptian Public Health entities. It centralizes prescription services for patients within healthcare centers and Ministry of Health entities under the UPA system, ensuring efficient and transparent medication management.
1
1
Key Features
Centralized Dispensing: Provides a unified platform for dispensing medications, linked to patient national IDs. This system allows for real-time tracking and management of prescriptions across all participating healthcare facilities.
2
2
Comprehensive Database
Maintains a detailed record of patient prescriptions and dispensed medications. The database includes information on dosage, frequency, and duration of medication use, facilitating better patient care and monitoring.
3
3
Controlled Medication Consumption
Monitors medication dispensing, whether in hospitals or outpatient facilities, ensuring appropriate use. The system flags potential misuse or overuse of medications, helping to prevent drug abuse and promote responsible medication practices.
4
4
Fraud Prevention
Prevents duplicate dispensing and fraudulent claims through rigorous tracking. Advanced algorithms detect and prevent fraudulent activities, ensuring the integrity of the medication dispensing process.
Benefits
Streamlined Prescription Management
Simplifies the dispensing process, connecting medications directly to patient records via national ID. This reduces administrative burden and improves the efficiency of healthcare providers.
Reduced Errors
Prevents duplicate prescriptions by allowing staff to view a patient's complete dispensing history. Real-time access to patient medication history minimizes the risk of prescribing errors and adverse drug interactions.
Automated Inventory Tracking
Automatically deducts dispensed medications from the entity's inventory. This ensures accurate inventory levels and prevents stockouts, optimizing medication availability for patients.
Detailed Reporting
Generates comprehensive patient reports, including prescription details and dispensing information. These reports provide valuable insights for healthcare administrators and policymakers, supporting data-driven decision-making and continuous improvement.
Central Pharmacy Workflow
1
Administrators are granted access and assigned specific entity warehouses or pharmacies. The system provides role-based access control, ensuring that only authorized personnel can access sensitive patient information.
2
Administrators search for patients by national ID, adding prescriptions for existing patients or registering new patients with basic information. The patient registration process is streamlined and user-friendly, allowing for quick and efficient enrollment of new patients.
3
Prescription data includes the patient's primary diagnosis, prescribing physician, and medication details. Detailed prescription information ensures accurate medication dispensing and reduces the risk of errors.
4
Administrators add required medications from the assigned warehouse or pharmacy. The system provides a comprehensive list of available medications, along with relevant information such as dosage, contraindications, and potential side effects.

Streamlining the Recall Process within the UPA Supply Chain
Overview
  • Integrate a comprehensive recalls process into the UPA supply chain platform to significantly enhance traceability and accountability across all stages.
Goal
  • Close the governance loop in the supply chain by establishing robust and traceable recall mechanisms specifically designed for healthcare products, ensuring public safety and regulatory compliance.
Objectives
  • Enhance governance oversight of product recalls.
  • Ensure complete coverage of the supply chain lifecycle from procurement to disposal.
Scope
  • Include all supply chain partners, from manufacturers to end-users.
  • Seamlessly integrate with existing procurement and supply systems to minimize disruption and maximize efficiency.
Stakeholders

  • Supply Chain Managers overseeing the movement and storage of products.
Timeline & Phases

  • Challenges in integrating with diverse supply chain data sources and formats.
Next Steps

Health Management Information System (HMIS)

Overview

Overview The Health Management Information System (HMIS) is a strategic initiative designed to consolidate procurement and inventory data across healthcare facilities within the UPA network. It aims to replace fragmented legacy systems with a centralized, digital platform, enhancing efficiency in stock monitoring, reporting, and emergency preparedness across more than 120 health centers.

Goal

Goal To establish a real-time, centralized health inventory and procurement system that integrates national-level data, providing transparent, automated reporting. This will lead to improved resource management, streamlined supply chain operations, and enhanced emergency response capabilities.

Objectives

Objectives Consolidate procurement and inventory data from 7 disparate legacy systems, including the Pharmacy Management System (PMS), Inventory Tracking System (ITS), and Procurement Database (PDB), into a unified HMIS database. Eliminate manual reporting processes through automation, replacing paper-based reports with real-time dashboards and automated reporting tools, reducing reporting time by 75%. Enable real-time visibility of stock levels (medicines, PPE, equipment), providing up-to-the-minute insights into inventory levels for essential medical supplies, personal protective equipment, and critical medical equipment across all health centers. Alert health centers and the Ministry of Health about low-stock or emergency supply needs through automated SMS and email alerts, ensuring timely replenishment of critical supplies and enabling proactive response to emergencies. Provide interactive dashboards for real-time monitoring and strategic planning, offering customizable views and data visualization tools to support informed decision-making at the facility, regional, and national levels. Improve coordination between UPA and MoH for medical supply chain governance, facilitating seamless data exchange and collaborative decision-making to optimize resource allocation and supply chain efficiency.

Scope

Scope Nationwide health facilities and MoH supply chain: Encompassing all UPA-affiliated health facilities and the MoH supply chain network, ensuring comprehensive coverage of the national healthcare system. 120+ health centers included in live monitoring: Integrating data from over 120 health centers into the HMIS platform, providing real-time insights into inventory levels, procurement activities, and supply chain performance. Integration with Ministry of Health systems: Establishing seamless data exchange between HMIS and existing MoH systems, such as the National Health Registry and Disease Surveillance System, to enhance data sharing and collaboration. Dashboards for decision-makers at UPA and MoH: Providing tailored dashboards for decision-makers at UPA and MoH, offering customizable views, data visualization tools, and real-time insights to support strategic planning and resource allocation. Automated alerts for inventory replenishment: Implementing automated alerts for inventory replenishment, notifying health centers and MoH operators when stock levels fall below pre-defined thresholds, ensuring timely replenishment of critical supplies.

Stakeholders

Stakeholders Ministry of Health: The primary government body responsible for healthcare policy and regulation, relying on HMIS for data-driven decision-making and resource allocation. Unified Procurement Authority (UPA): The central procurement agency responsible for sourcing and distributing medical supplies, utilizing HMIS to optimize procurement processes and supply chain efficiency. Health facility managers: The frontline healthcare providers responsible for managing inventory levels and ensuring adequate supply of essential medical supplies, relying on HMIS for real-time monitoring and automated alerts. IT & data migration teams: The technical experts responsible for integrating legacy systems, migrating data, and ensuring the ongoing maintenance and support of the HMIS platform. Emergency logistics planners: The personnel responsible for coordinating emergency response efforts and ensuring timely delivery of medical supplies to affected areas, relying on HMIS for real-time monitoring and situational awareness. Data analytics and reporting teams: The data specialists responsible for analyzing HMIS data, generating reports, and providing insights to support decision-making at all levels of the healthcare system.

Timeline & Phases

Timeline & Phases ✅ Phase 1 – System Design & Legacy Analysis: Completed analysis of 7 legacy systems, including PMS, ITS, PDB, and HRIS, and their respective data structures, identifying key data elements, data flows, and integration points. ✅ Phase 2 – Integration & Development: Integrated data pipelines and middleware with MoH systems, such as the National Health Registry and Disease Surveillance System, enabling seamless data exchange and interoperability. ✅ Phase 3 – Data Migration & Testing: Completed migration of legacy data and initial testing for consistency and real-time sync, validating data accuracy, completeness, and timeliness across all integrated systems. 🔄 Phase 4 – Dashboard Customization & Alert Automation: Designing tailored dashboards and configuring automated alerts based on inventory thresholds, collaborating with stakeholders to define key performance indicators (KPIs), data visualization requirements, and alert notification rules. 🟢 Phase 5 – Go-Live & Feedback Collection: Prepare for full deployment across all health centers with user training and monitoring for issues, conducting comprehensive user training programs and establishing a feedback loop for continuous improvement.

Dependencies & Risks

Dependencies & Risks Dependencies: Full data access from legacy systems: Ensuring timely and unrestricted access to all relevant data from legacy systems, including historical data, real-time updates, and metadata. Timely participation from MoH IT team: Securing the active participation and collaboration of the MoH IT team in the integration, testing, and deployment of HMIS. Compatibility with UPA's central system infrastructure: Ensuring seamless integration and compatibility between HMIS and UPA's central system infrastructure, including network connectivity, security protocols, and data storage capacity. Risks: Data inconsistencies from legacy sources: Addressing potential data inconsistencies, errors, and redundancies arising from legacy sources through data cleansing, validation, and standardization processes. Resistance to change at local health centers: Overcoming potential resistance to change among staff at local health centers through comprehensive training, communication, and change management strategies. Potential delays in dashboard configuration due to scope expansion: Managing the risk of potential delays in dashboard configuration due to scope expansion through rigorous project management, prioritization of requirements, and agile development methodologies.

Next Steps

Conduct pilot launch in selected regions before full rollout: Conducting a pilot launch of HMIS in selected regions to validate system performance, gather user feedback, and refine deployment processes. Objectives

Monitor compliance with national safety standards for biomedical equipment. Ensure safe and traceable decommissioning and disposal of obsolete or non-functional devices. Integrate maintenance and decommissioning with UPA Assets and Inventory Management systems.

Scope

Use of event driven systems (ex. Kafka)

An Event-Driven System is an architectural paradigm where components communicate and respond to changes in state by producing and consuming events . Instead of relying on continuous polling or tight coupling between systems, actions are triggered asynchronously by events—such as a user action, a system update, or an external input.

This model promotes scalability, flexibility, and real-time responsiveness, making it ideal for modern applications like microservices, e-commerce platforms, and IoT solutions. ✅ Key Benefits Loose coupling between services Real-time processing of data and actions High scalability and responsiveness Enables asynchronous workflows Facilitates microservices and serverless architectures
